title: Mario Draghi calls for eurozone fiscal policy to be more growth-friendly - business live | Business | The Guardian
summary: draghi : eurozone fiscal policy should become more growth-friendly .
mario draghi : ecb stands ready to do more .
janet yellen speech begins at jackson hole .
fed official urges ecb to act .
co-op bank planning more job cuts .
business leaders plan `` united statement against scottish independence ''

text: here 's the official line from the ecb : ecb ( @ ecb ) draghi : measures announced by the ecb should provide the intended boost to demand and we stand ready to adjust our policy stance further
lorcan roche kelly ( @ lorcanrk ) draghi conclusion : need both `` higher aggregate demand and determined structural reform '' i take it higher means `` more than now ''
frederik ducrozet ( @ fwred ) draghi on fiscal policy ( hint : both parts equally important ) : `` it should be possible to lower the tax burden in a budget-neutral way '' .

documents.title: draghi : eurozone fiscal policy should become more growth-friendly
text: this is important .
mario draghi 's speech at jackson hole includes a call for a change to the eurozone 's austerity programmes to stimulate growth .

here 's the key section from the ecb president 's speech : turning to fiscal policy , since 2010 the euro area has suffered from fiscal policy being less available and effective , especially compared with other large advanced economies .
this is not so much a consequence of high initial debt ratios - public debt is in aggregate not higher in the euro area than in the us or japan .
it reflects the fact that the central bank in those countries could act and has acted as a backstop for government funding .
this is an important reason why markets spared their fiscal authorities the loss of confidence that constrained many euro area governments ' market access .
this has in turn allowed fiscal consolidation in the us and japan to be more backloaded .

thus , it would be helpful for the overall stance of policy if fiscal policy could play a greater role alongside monetary policy , and i believe there is scope for this , while taking into account our specific initial conditions and legal constraints .
these initial conditions include levels of government expenditure and taxation in the euro area that are , in relation to gdp , already among the highest in the world .
and we are operating within a set of fiscal rules - the stability and growth pact - which acts as an anchor for confidence and that would be self-defeating to break .
he then calls for growth-friendly fiscal policies to encourage a up in activity in the whole region .
draghi makes four suggestions : first , the existing flexibility within the rules could be used to better address the weak recovery and to make room for the cost of needed structural reforms .
second , there is leeway to achieve a more growth-friendly composition of fiscal policies .
as a start , it should be possible to lower the tax burden in a budget-neutral way .

[ 15 ] this strategy could have positive effects even in the short-term if taxes are lowered in those areas where the short-term fiscal multiplier is higher , and expenditures cut in unproductive areas where the multiplier is lower .
research suggests positive second-round effects on business confidence and private investment could also be achieved in the short-term .
[ 16 ] third , in parallel it may be useful to have a discussion on the overall fiscal stance of the euro area .
unlike in other major advanced economies , our fiscal stance is not based on a single budget voted for by a single parliament , but on the aggregation of eighteen national budgets and the eu budget .
stronger coordination among the different national fiscal stances should in principle allow us to achieve a more growth-friendly overall fiscal stance for the euro area .

fourth , complementary action at the eu level would also seem to be necessary to ensure both an appropriate aggregate position and a large public investment programme - which is consistent with proposals by the incoming president of the european commission .
mario draghi is defending the eurozone 's austerity measure ( which many experts criticise for undermining the recovery and causing long-term damage ) .
he argues it was essential to rebuild market confidence ; even though it was his own whatever it takes '' speech that actually calmed the crisis in july 2012 .
joseph weisenthal ( @ thestalwart ) sorry draghi , but this is still revisionist bullshit .
lorcan roche kelly ( @ lorcanrk ) chart 7 from @ twitterid draghi - there 's euro area 's lost decade on the left
the crux of mario draghi 's speech is that the path to higher employment in the euro area is a policy mix that combines monetary , fiscal and structural measures .

mario draghi , the man who saved the eurozone two years ago by promising to do whatever it takes '' , has also flagged up that the us ( growing at 4 % per year ) and the eurozone ( stagnating ) are diverging .
he includes this chart , showing how the eurozone labour market has performed so poorly in different years .
photograph : /ecb cnbcworld ( @ cnbcworld ) ecb president draghi says he sees diverging path of u.s. and european monetary policies :

documents.title: mario draghi : ecb stands ready to do more
text: breaking : mario draghi is on his feet at jackson hole , and telling fellow top central bankers that the european central bank is prepared to take more measures to stimulate the economy if needed .
the ecb chief said he and his fellow policymakers stand ready to adjust their policy stance , if circumstances merit it .

fabrizio goria ( @ fgoria ) draghi - `` we stand ready to adjust our policy stance further '' - rtrs but he is also saying that he believes the measures announced in june - including hundreds of billions of euros of fresh cheap loans for eurozone banks , will work .
the speech is online here : lorcan roche kelly ( @ lorcanrk ) boom draghi speech
reaction keeps coming in : david wessel ( @ davidmwessel ) feroli on yellen : `` likely passed the `` two charlie test '' hawks like plosser and doves like evans ok with it .
did n't front run fomc .
mohamed el-erian , chief economic adviser of allianz ( and former ceo of bond-trading giant pimco ) , has given janet yellen a decent score for today 's speech .

over on bloomberg , he writes : her presentation did a great job of framing important analytical issues , setting the tone not only for the subsequent discussions at the conference but also for research that will follow in the weeks and months to come .
specifically , she described the difficulties confronting an assessment of today 's labor market , including the challenges facing an evaluation of the remaining slack in employment .

this takes in factors such as the labor participation rate , wage dynamics , involuntary part-time employment and the extent to which the decline in the unemployment rate somewhat overstates the improvement in overall labor market conditions . ''
el-erian also points out that yellen steered away from global issues , keeping focus on the labor market .
yellen was silent on the issue of how to navigate the intensifying multispeed policy world of central banking in developed countries .
her main dilemma now is how quickly to ease off the monetary-policy accelerator .
this is a stark contrast to the challenge facing european central bank president mario draghi .
he is dealing with the question of when and how to step harder on the accelerator .
bloomberg view ( @ bv ) yellen sets the jackson hole agenda and ( mostly ) does n't disappoint : by @ twitterid

documents.title: one step backwards from that rate hike
text: capital economics reckons that the federal reserve chair has inched back from the more hawkish tone of this month 's monetary policy meeting .

they say : if the release of the minutes of july 's fomc meeting on wednesday suggested that the fed had taken two steps closer to raising interest rates , then today 's speech by fed chair janet yellen at jackson hole could be interpreted as it taking one step back .
however , capital economics still expects that the first rate hike will come in march next year , as james bullard of the st louis fed predicted earlier today .

documents.title: european markets end lower
text: after a positive week despite geopolitical tensions - notably the situation in ukraine - and hints that interest rates in the uk and us may rise sooner than previously thought , european markets paused for breath ahead of the weekend .

the closing scores were : the ftse 100 finished down 2.41 points or 0.04 % at 6775.25 germany 's dax dipped 0.66 % at 9339.17 france 's cac closed 0.93 % lower at 4252.80 italy 's ftse mib ended 0.46 % down at 19,917.98 spain 's ibex fell 0.53 % to 10,500.2 on wall street , the dow jones industrial average is down around 8 points or 0.04 % .

here 's our wall street correspondent dominic rushe , on janet yellen 's speech : federal reserve chairwoman janet yellen said on friday that the us economy was improving but warned there was a possibility that the severe recession caused persistent changes in the labour market 's functioning '' .
yellen 's first speech at the annual meeting of global central bankers in jackson hole , wyoming , focussed largely on the jobs market .
the economy has made considerable progress in recovering from the largest and most sustained loss of employment in the united states since the great depression , '' she said .
these developments are encouraging , but it speaks to the depth of the damage that , five years after the end of the recession , the labour market has yet to fully recover . ''
the us has now added more than 200,000 jobs each month for six months in a row .

yellen said that despite the improvements the fed was awaiting more evidence about the health of labour markets before deciding when to start raising interest rates more here : fed chair janet yellen cautious in speech on 'damaged ' us economy
it also appears that geopolitics , rather than events in wyoming , is weighing on the us stock market .
traders do n't like the sound of russia 's aid convoy crossing the ukraine border uninvited .
the s & p 500 has dipped by 0.2 % to its lowest point of the day .
joseph weisenthal ( @ thestalwart ) s & p near lods .
traders using the word `` ukraine ''

documents.title: coming up later mario draghi
text: unfortunately , the jackson hole speeches do n't appear to be streamed online anywhere .
the next major event is mario draghi 's address , in three and a half hour 's time ( 7.30pm bst , or 2.30pm new york ) .
draghi 's speech could outline what the european central bank is willing , and able , to do to counter the worrying slowdown in the eurozone economy .
i 'll aim to post the key points from that speech once it happens ( the newswires should have it under embargo )

documents.title: ing : yellen skirts around the issues
text: most pundits had expected janet yellen 's speech to be largely inconsequential '' , and that 's exactly what we got .

so argues rob carnell , ing 's economist , who also provides a handy summary of the key points : fed chair , janet yellen , skirted around the issue of future monetary policy by noting that whilst there were a number of factors that might mean the labour market was less of a threat to inflation than in previous business cycles , equally , there were factors that might make it more so .
whilst clearly yellen gives more weight to the former arguments , she also acknowledged that the labour market had made improvements .
as such , this was classic , economist on the one hand and on the other '' , and gives nothing away .
the key theme might be summarised as uncertainty '' .
and the fed ty likes to play safe with monetary policy when it is unsure .
that said , we continue to think that the tone of the fomc in september will be somewhat more hawkish than it has been recently , and look to recent fomc minutes as a hint in this direction .

this is not to say that there will be a sea-change in the fed 's stance , but enough of a shift to encourage thoughts of an earlier-than-expected first fed rate hike , and possibly cause a bit more selling pressure at the front end of the yield curve and dollar strength .
we also think that the chances of an april 2015 rate hike remain good , with the economy up pace in recent months , and leaving the housing-related and weather weakness of 1h2014 behind .

whilst it is tempting to think that this may result in an eventual and perhaps sharp rise in longer dated bond yields , evidence so far this year is building that the economy continues to need low bond yields in order to make progress , and as such , any sell offs are likely to be self-defeating and short-lived .
this word cloud shows how 'labor ' and 'market ' dominates janet yellen 's speech , with inflation '' coming behind : steve goldstein ( @ mktwgoldstein ) the word cloud of yellen 's speech
there 's a fairly muted reaction to janet yellen 's speech at jackson hole ( highlights start here ) .
the us dollar has risen against the euro .
one euro is now worth $ 1.323 , down half a cent .
us bonds have fallen slightly in value , pushing up the yield ( interest rate ) on 10-year treasury 's by a mere three basis points to 2.43 % , from 2.40 % .

that suggests her speech hinted at an earlier normalisation of policy : joseph brusuelas ( @ joebrusuelas ) given yellen acknowledgement of structural factors in the under utilization of labor resources , the hawkish reaction is not surprising .
but on the other hand peter coy ( @ petercoy ) most dovish idea in yellen speech : possibility of `` pent-up wage deflation . ''
janet yellen concluded her speech by saying that us interest rates could rise sooner than expected if the labor market improves more rapidly than expected , or if inflation up faster .
but on the other hand , if economic performance turns out to be disappointing '' the fed could maintain a more accommodative stance for longer .
indeed christopher vecchio ( @ cvecchiofx ) fed 's yellen says rate hikes could come sooner if labor market progresses faster .
also , if it rains , you might get wet .
$ fed

binyamin appelbaum of the new york times sums up the key points : binyamin appelbaum ( @ bcappelbaum ) yellen holds the line on policy , and downplays the importance of inflation as an indicator : binyamin appelbaum ( @ bcappelbaum ) this yellen speech is a direct rebuttal to gop/taylor proposal for fed to announce a rule .
she 's arguing life is far too complicated .
binyamin appelbaum ( @ bcappelbaum ) yellen 's comments on inflation are important : she 's arguing that it is not , by itself , a reliable indicator that it 's time to raise rates .

documents.title: yellen : inflation might not trigger rate rise alone
text: janet yellen then outlined the challenge of trying to assess the amount of spare capacity in the labour market .
she explains that there 's a risk that the fed will fail to act fast enough ; it could miss inflationary pressures if wages rise unusually slowly .

if downward nominal wage rigidities created a stock of pent-up wage deflation during the economic downturn , observed wage and price pressures associated with a given amount of slack or pace of reduction in slack might be unusually low for a time .
if so , the first clear signs of inflation pressure could come later than usual in the progression toward maximum employment .

as a result , maintaining a high degree of monetary policy accommodation until inflation pressures emerge could , in this case , unduly delay the removal of accommodation , necessitating an abrupt and potentially disruptive tightening of policy later on .
that 's the hawkish view .

but yellen immediately sounds dovish , explaining why the fed could blunder by putting too much emphasis on inflation conversely , profound dislocations in the labor market in recent years-such as depressed participation associated with worker discouragement and a still-substantial level of long-term unemployment-may cause inflation pressures to arise earlier than usual as the degree of slack in the labor market declines .
however , some of the resulting wage and price pressures could subsequently ease as higher real wages draw workers back into the labor force and lower long-term unemployment .

as a consequence , tightening monetary policy as soon as inflation moves back toward 2 percent might , in this case , prevent labor markets from recovering fully and so would not be consistent with the dual mandate .
reminder : the speech is online here .

documents.title: yellen : us has made `` considerable progress '' , but
text: janet yellen began her speech with an upbeat statement , that over the last five years the us economy has made considerable progress in recovering from the largest and most sustained loss of employment in the united states since the great depression : '' .
th unemployment rate , for example , has dropped by 4 percentage points since 2009 to just 6.2 % ( almost half the level in the struggling eurozone ) .
but there was swiftly a caveat : it speaks to the depth of the damage that , five years after the end of the recession , the labor market has yet to fully recover .

janet yellen tells economists at jackson hole that more nuance '' is needed : assessments of the degree of remaining slack in the labor market need to become more nuanced because of considerable uncertainty about the level of employment consistent with the federal reserve 's dual mandate [ of price stability and full employment ] ''
fabrizio goria ( @ fgoria ) goldman sachs says yellen 's speech `` seems to be fairly hedged '' nothing particularly shocking .
heidi n. moore ( @ moorehn ) here 's the text of yellen 's speech .
still ca n't find video .

documents.title: janet yellen speech begins at jackson hole
text: breaking : janet yellen has said there is no simple recipe '' to devise the right monetary policy to tackle america 's labour market .
she also warned that the fed faces difficult judgements when deciding when the us jobs market is strong enough to cope with an interest rate rise .

highlights from her speech are fizzling over the newswires : 15:00 - fed 's yellen says no simple recipe '' for appropriate policy in current u.s. labor market context 15:00 - yellen : still unclear degree of remaining labor slack , how quickly it will disappear 15:00 - yellen : tightening policy too soon as inflation moves toward 2 percent might prevent labor market from fully recovering 15:00 - yellen says fed emphasis shifting to determining what labor conditions would bring about less accommodation 15:00 - yellen : fed needs to make difficult judgments '' about cyclical , structural influences on labor market 15:00 - yellen urges caution in judging that recent wage data points to weaker labor conditions than indicated by unemployment rate 15:00 - yellen : could reasonably expect further increases in labor demand to pull sizable share of discouraged workers back into work force more to follow stubbs/reuters
nearly time for janet yellen 's opening speech in jackson hole .
deutsche bank economist jim reid reckons the fed chair will focus on the question of how much slack remains in the us labour market .
business insider has the details : so what can we expect from yellen ?

our us economists expect the fed chair to provide us with an updated assessment on the infamous 'yellen dashboard ' in evaluating the ongoing labour market slack and how they have yet to normalise relative to 2002-2007 levels .
some of these alternative measures she monitors include duration of unemployment , quit rate in jolts data , labour force participation etc .
any sound bite that touches on the debate of cyclical versus structural drivers of labour force participation will also be closely followed .

unlike some of the previous jackson hole symposiums , this is likely not one that will serve as a precursor of any monetary policy changes but the tone of yellen 's speech may still have a market impact and set the mood for busier times ahead in september .
given markets are seemingly expecting nothing but another dovish display from yellen the risk is perhaps skewed to the other side .
shares have dipped on wall street at the start of trading , as investors await janet yellen 's speech .
the dow jones index is 0.16 % lower , dropping 26 points to 17,011 .
and the s & p 100 dipped a little from yesterday 's record closing high .

us government bonds are trading flat , reuters points out : u.s. 10-yr treasury price unchanged , yield at 2.40 pct ahead of fed chair janet yellen 's jackson hole speech due at 10:00 a.m. edt ( 1400 gmt ) in london , the ftse is down just 10 points .
germany 's dax is down 0.4 % , and france 's cac is down 0.75 % , as russia 's decision to sent its aid convoy into ukraine without permission weighs on europe 's markets .

documents.title: fed official urges ecb to act
text: james bullard is a busy bee .
he 's now told reuters that the european central bank needs to agree new stimulus measures to help the eurozone economy recover .

the president of the st. louis federal reserve bank chipped in , just hours before mario draghi addresses the jackson hole symposium , warning : if europe as a whole goes into recession , that would be a serious issue from the perspective of us monetary policy . ''

bullard cited europe 's low inflation rate , which has sagged to just 0.4 % : to me , that 's a flashing signal to the ecb that they need to take actions that are sufficient to reassure markets that they 're going to hit their targets over the near term . ''
bloomberg have kindly sent found the transcript of their interview with james bullard , of the federal reserve bank of st. louis .

as flagged earlier , bullard predicted that the us fed will raise rates just seven months time , in march 2015 : the evidence is leading toward an earlier increase that would have been in the works earlier this year .
labor markets have improved quite a bit relative to what the committee was thinking . ''
there was also an interesting exchange with bloomberg 's kathleen hays , who pointed to europe 's weaknesses , and the geopolitical tensions over ukraine .
hays : well , more - it seems - more and more numbers , you know , the economic numbers on your part are not getting better .
they seem to be getting worse .
more bad numbers out of germany .
and one of the guests on my show recently , and how could the fed move now ?
how could the fed signal ?
even signal a move to raise the rate at a time when you 've got the ukraine-russia conflict and the sanctions , and europe getting weaker .
this would n't be prudent .
of course , the fed would n't make a move at a time like this .
bullard : well , i do n't know what your guest was thinking , but let me just paint the the opposite way .
u.s. is growing at three percent , unemployment has dropped a point over the last year .
job growth is a real bust , and they are a long away from normal .

they should get going on normalization , and then for europe , you know , they might look to additional stimulus , although , you know , and i have advocated qe for europe , and then it seems like you get the exchange rate movements in the direct - at least , pressure will go in the direction that you want , given that situation , a slowing europe and a growing u.s .
fabrizio goria ( @ fgoria ) bearish mode : on - > rt @ twitterid :
a handy reminder for jackson hole attendees of how the us economy has improved since last year 's meeting : bloomberg news ( @ bloombergnews ) what a difference a year makes :
i predict a scramble : robin harding ( @ robinbharding ) what i 've learned about jackson hole : there are only six available power points .
arrive early .
a flurry of comments from federal reserve policymakers have just hit the wires , setting the scene for jackson hole .
it includes regular hawk james bullard , who says us interest rates will rise in the first quarter of next year .

that 's earlier than other fed officials have suggested ( bullard himself wo n't have a vote on the fomc until 2016 , though ) ransquawk ( @ ransquawk ) triple # fed whammy bullard sees rate liftoff q1 2015 , lockhart mid 2015 and plosser says fed should signal earlier rate rise on economy fabrizio goria ( @ fgoria ) fed 's bullard says federal open market committee has been too pessimistic on unemployment - rtrs

documents.title: jackson hole : a preamble
text: federal reserve chair janet yellen speaking with ady barkan of the center for popular democracy yesterday ( his t-shirt reads 'what recovery ? ' )
locher/ap this year 's jackson hole economic policy symposium kicks off in a couple of hours ( 3pm bst ) , bringing together top central bankers from across the globe .

this year 's event is titled re-evaluating labor market dynamics '' - a crucial issue right now , with the federal reserve and the bank of england trying to assess how much employment slack remains in their respective spheres .

but while fed and the boe are both inching towards normalising monetary policy , the other two big central banks - the european central bank and the bank of japan - could both expand their stimulus measures in the future .
that 's why mario draghi 's speech late tonight ( 7.30pm bst ) could be particularly interesting - will be respond to the latest weak economic data , showing the eurozone stagnating ?
economist shaun richards comments : the euro area looks as though it may already be turning down again after not much of a recovery as france and italy in particular struggle .
so a meeting at which one might expect an unwinding of central bank activity may in fact have premonitions of further expansion in europe .
is this our future where several of the main central banks are always expanding policy ?
shaun richards ( @ notayesmansecon ) what will central bankers be discussing at jackson hole ?
via @ twitterid # fed janet yellen 's opening address ( 3pm bst ) will also be closely watched for any signals regarding future interest rate rises .

kit juckes of societe generale reckons she is likely to sound rather cautious today ; a contrast with the latest minutes from the fed 's monetary policy committee : after the hawkish bias to fomc minutes , the dovish camp gets its chance to sound off at jackson hole .

marc ostwald of adm investor services agrees : the whisper on the street would have us believe that ms yellen will take a more forcefully dovish line in today 's speech at jackson hole , despite rather less dovish '' tones to the july fomc minutes , and one can assume that there will be rather too much verbiage devoted by the financial community to 'analysing ' the nuances of the speech , and the implications for the policy outlook , above all the timing of normalization lift-off '' .

whereby the term normalization would be better described as a step into the unknown , given that the whole process of financial intermediation has changed so drastically , and there is no precedent for exiting from such a protracted , and policy induced , period of capital misallocation .
there 's also one big change this year - wall street economists are n't welcome .
janet yellen has tightened the invite list ; perhaps keen to ditch the idea that jackson hole gave financial players valuable insight into central bank thinking .
instead , there are guests such as william spriggs , chief economist of the afl-cio , the umbrella organisation for the us union movement , the ft flags up .
locher/ap

russia 's economy ministry has reported that its economy kept shrinking last month gdp fell by 0.2 % year-on-year during july , following a 0.1 % contraction in june , suggesting that the ukraine crisis down its already weak economy .
russian workers have been reporting signs of falling demand , and weak wage growth , this summer .
there are fears russia could fall into recession if geopolitical tensions do n't ease .
so far this year , gdp has risen by 0.7 % , the ministry reported .
on the other hand , there are also more conciliatory quotes from ukraine on the wires : jonathan ferro ( @ ferrotv ) first ukraine says they see russian aid convoy as an invasion .
now they say they allowed it to avoid provocation .
can we rely on anything ?
lorcan roche kelly ( @ lorcanrk ) invitation > invasion rt @ twitterid first : ukraine allows invasion .
no longer invasion .

shares in moscow are falling further , as ukraine expresses its anger over russia sending its aid convoy across the border without an agreement : ransquawk ( @ ransquawk ) ukraine sees russian aid convoy as invasion according to the ukraine head of security council ! !
steve collins ( @ tradedesk steve ) russia 's micex index extends losses , dropping 1.7 %
other european markets have been inching down through the morning .
the french cac has lost 0.7 % so far , and germany 's dax is down nearly 0.5 % .
reuters shares fell on the news that russia 's aid convoy has crossed the ukraine border this morning , while battles rage between kiev 's forces and moscow-backed rebels in donetsk and luhansk .
russian aid convoy clears customs at east ukraine border russia insists the mission is simply to provide help , but some ukrainian politicians fear darker motives .
the convoy had been paused at the border while both sides argued about how the trucks would be inspected and monitored .
russia appears to have decided to sent the trucks on regardless .
the ft reports : it is impossible to put up with this mayhem , blatant lies and this unwillingness to agree any longer , '' the russian foreign ministry said in a statement on its website on friday .
peter spiegel ( @ spiegelpeter ) at midday presser , @ twitterid commission says there are `` conflicting reports '' on whether # russia convoy has crossed into # ukraine .
there are ?
with a long weekend looming , it appears that many in the city have already clocked off - or keeping their heads down until janet yellen 's speech at the jackson hole symposium at 3pm uk time .
the ftse 100 remains flat ( down just 7 points ) .

will hedden of ig reports that some market-watchers are desperately counting the days until september and a little more action '' the market expects a dovish offering from fed chair janet yellen when she speaks early in the us trading day .
and mario draghi 's speech ( 7.30pm bst ) could provide a spark : it might be time to start explaining the what in 'whatever it takes ' if the slide in european data is to be halted .
all looks quiet in brussels too : peter spiegel ( @ spiegelpeter ) my 1st @ twitterid commission midday presser since coming back from holiday .
does n't seem to be hopping , does it ?

documents.title: photos : protesters at jackson hole
text: the world 's top central bankers ca n't avoid seeing the public 's anger over the state of the global economy , even though they 've schlepped out to rural wyoming .
protesters gathered at jackson hole , venue for the annual economic policy symposium .
their message is that many millions of ordinary people around the globe have n't yet felt the benefits of the recovery '' since the financial crisis .
here 's a few photos from yesterday : stubbs/reuters narayana kocherlakota , president and ceo of the federal reserve bank of minneapolis , arriving at the opening reception .

stubbs/reuters robin harding ( @ robinbharding ) jackson hole had protesters this year robin harding ( @ robinbharding ) jackson hole protester says `` why are they hiding in a place like this that is so hard to get to ? ''
got a point there .
co-op bank ceo niall booker also admitted that the exodus of customer accounts , down almost 30,000 so far this year , was very painful .
the loss of any customer is a mortal wound '' ( not literally , we trust ) to an experienced banker like himself .

however , it could have ben even worse booker says : considering the amount of time that we spent receiving negative publicity in the cusp of the first and second quarters , i think the reduction is not significant and probably less than we would have expected . ''
some customers may have quit the co-op after it raised the fees on certain accounts , such as its privilege premium service .

john-paul ford rojas ( @ jpfordrojas ) booker says the loss of any customer feels like a `` mortal wound '' james titcomb ( @ jamestitcomb ) co-op bank boss niall booker says each customer he loses is `` a mortal wound '' .
losing 28,199 must really hurt then

documents.title: co-op bank planning more job cuts
text: co-op bank 's chief executive has warned that the company plans to keep cutting jobs , on top of the 1,560 workers 'let go ' in the last year .
speaking after announcing a £ 75m loss this morning ( details here ) , niall booker warned that one or two more redundancy programmes '' may be needed .
booker told reporters that : a large proportion of our cost is in people and , consequently , we will continue to see job reductions .

there have been one or two redundancy programmes and i believe there will be one or two more in that respect '' booker also warned that co-op bank does n't expect to return to profit this year , or in 2015 .
clear asset finance ( @ clearaf leasing ) co-op 's loses are n't as big as they expected , but £ 76mil down is nothing to sniffle at .
customers jumping ship
shaun richards ( @ notayesmansecon ) here is the statement announcing the co-operative bank 's losses of £ 76 million .

documents.title: business leaders plan `` united statement against scottish independence ''
text: over one hundred of britain 's business leaders are planning to wade into the scottish independence vote by urging scots to preserve the union .
that 's according to the daily telegraph today , which reckons the joint letter could be a a hammerblow '' for snp leader alex salmond .

scottish business leaders prepare to unite against independence louise armitstead , the telegraph 's chief business correspondent , reports that the business people involved all have operations north of the border : keith cochrane , chief executive of the glasgow-based engineer weir group , is behind the move and has spent weeks persuading chairmen , chief executives and entrepreneurs to sign a joint letter urging voters to reject independence for the sake of economic prosperity .

planned as the most comprehensive and powerful statement from the scottish business community to date , the business list is expected to include bosses from publicly listed companies and retailers , as well as financial services leaders and an army of small and medium-sized business leaders .

those approached include city heavyweights such as donald brydon , the chairman of royal mail ; bill gammell , the former scottish rugby player and boss of cairn energy ; angus cockburn , interim chief executive of the power company aggreko ; and ben van beurden , chief executive of the oil giant shell .
however , the bulk of the list is deliberately made up of small and medium-sized business managers and entrepreneurs .

news of the letter emerges as hsbc chairman douglas flint warns that scotland could suffer a capital flight '' if it breaks away from the rest of the uk flint cited uncertainty over what currency it would use , and on what terms , warning : the transition from the existing currency union would be complex and fraught with danger '' .
timesbusiness ( @ timesbusiness ) the @ twitterid biz section leads with the hsbc boss saying that scottish independence could lead to capital flight .
stan shamu of ig says investors expect janet yellen to remain fairly dovish '' in her speech later today , focusing on measures of labour market slack that support continued policy accommodation '' .
there 's a nervous feel in the financial markets as many of the world 's top central bankers gather in jackson hole , wyoming , for their annual meeting .
janet yellen , head of the us federal reserve , will give a speech at 3pm bst which might give new insights into her view of the global economy , and the prospects of a us rate rise .
mario draghi , president of the european central bank , is also giving a speech , but not until 7.30pm bst .
that has left investors reluctant to do anything too decisive .

europe 's stock markets are barely shifting in early trading , with the ftse 100 up just half a point , or +0.01 % ransquawk ( @ ransquawk ) its oh so quiet ransquawk ( @ ransquawk ) yellen at 1500bst/0900cdt , draghi at 1930bst/1330cdt , thats the only thing for today ransquawk ( @ ransquawk ) european equity moves this morning : lonmin +3.3 % , hugo boss +2.0 % , vodafone +0.8 % , halfords -3.0 %
edf insists that it did its best to avoid customer disruption over its it migration , and took on hundreds of extra staff were recruited to restore service levels '' once things went wrong .
but it accepts that it did fail some customers .

the £ 3m package announced today wo n't go directly to those people , though , as beatrice bigois , edf energy 's managing director of customers , explains : despite our best efforts and extensive planning to manage this transition in 2011 without impacting our customers , we recognise that for a period of time the service to our customers was not up to the standards they deserve .
we apologise to those customers who were impacted during this period .
we have cooperated fully with ofgem and have taken this matter very seriously .

the £ 3m package that we are offering will ensure that thousands of vulnerable customers are provided with free , independent advice on debt , as well as information to help them manage their energy consumption and bills . ''

documents.title: edf to pay £ 3m over complaints failings
text: the logo of edf energy .
nicholson/pa britain 's edf energy is to hand over £ 3m to groups representing 'vulnerable customers ' after failing to handle complaints properly .
an investigation by the industry watchdog , ofgem , found the company had breached complaint handling rules during a mass migration to a it system three years ago .
complaints surged by 30 % , as glitches during the migration left edf unable to receive , record and process some complaints for over six months , from may 2011 to january 2012 .
in an sobering report this morning , ofgem said many customers simply hung up because waiting times were too long .

for those who persevered , edf was often unable to properly record the details of their problems sarah harrison , ofgem 's senior partner with responsibility for enforcement , said companies need to do better when handing such migrations : edfenergy failed to have sufficiently robust processes in place when they introduced a new it system and this led to the unacceptable handling of complaints .

their commitment to putting things right and paying £ 3 million to the citizens advice energy best deal extra scheme and the plymouth citizen advice bureau 's debt helpline to benefit vulnerable customers is a step in the right direction to rebuilding consumer trust . ''
edf has already admitted that its customers suffered significant disruption during the it changeover , and publicly apologised .
a co-operative bank branch sign .
stillwell/pa those co-op bank customers who have stuck with the company despite its recent turmoil may have seen their local branch close .

today 's results ( the first since it posted a £ 1.3bn in 2013 ) show that it has cut its payroll by 21 percent in the past year to 5,860 and closed 46 branches , reducing its branch network by 16 percent since the start of the year .
another 25 branches will close in the fourth quarter , it said .

documents.title: summary
text: good morning , and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets , the world economy , business and finance .

documents.title: co-op bank posts £ 75m loss
text: the first big news of the morning is that britain 's bruised co-operative bank has reported a £ 75m loss for the first half of 2014 .
it also revealed that more than 20,000 customers have left amid its recent troubles .
today 's loss is an improvement on the £ 845m loss recorded a year ago - impairment charges and operating costs have both improved .
co-op bank was dragged into crisis last year as a £ 1.5bn black hole opened up in its balance sheet , forcing the co-operative group to relinquish control to a group of hedge funds .
today 's figures show the bank has cut 13 % of its staff so far this year , and the bank has also lost customers - with a net loss of 28,199 current accounts this year .

chief executive niall booker insists that the company is on the road to recovery , but still has a way to go : by the measures of capital and liquidity the bank is considerably stronger than it was a year ago , '' `` we are ahead of schedule in the disposal of non-core assets and have improved governance , particularly at board level .
however , the issues we continue to face in building a sustainable business are deep rooted and there remains much to be done . ''
